keyTakeAways: The landmark trial marks one of the first legal actions to hold social media companies accountable for the psychological harm caused by addictive app designs targeting youth.
Judge Carolyn Kuhl ruled that executives like Mark Zuckerberg and Evan Spiegel must testify in person, emphasizing the unique relevance of CEO testimony in proving negligence.

The companies' defense under the 1990s Communications Decency Act — which shields them from liability for user-generated content — has been rejected due to claims of design negligence and failure to protect young users.
Parents and school districts allege that features like like alerts and addictive user interfaces were intentionally designed, ignoring known mental health risks.
Meta and Snap argue that changes to platform design would harm business, but the court found that such decisions are central to assessing negligence.
The trial is part of a broader wave of litigation and political scrutiny on social media’s mental health impact, with TikTok and YouTube also named in the suit.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A landmark trial in Los Angeles is set to begin in January 2025, requiring top executives from Meta (Mark Zuckerberg, Adam Mosseri) and Snap (Evan Spiegel) to testify in person, after Judge Carolyn Kuhl ruled that their personal knowledge of platform design and business decisions is essential to proving negligence. The case consolidates hundreds of claims from parents and school districts accusing social media companies of designing addictive features—like like alerts—that exploit young users and ignore known mental health risks. Despite arguments that federal law protects them from liability for user content, the judge found that the companies' failure to implement safeguards constitutes negligence. The trial is among the first to hold such platforms legally responsible for harm caused by their app designs, marking a pivotal moment in legal and public scrutiny of social media's impact on youth.
title: Zuckerberg to testify in landmark social media trial
